ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about Greek sculptures, architecture and paintings. I analyzing the meaning of classicism and how classical references are portrayed in modern work.
I learned about the way classical art has been interpreted throughout various historical eras.

This was a great course that encouraged me to think critically about art and the context in which it was made and studied. I'd never considered classicism to have such diverse and complicated definitions, and it was a wonderful first art history course to take. I will take so many of the lessons on composition, style, history, and art-as-conversation with me into the future.
Visual analysis, comparison, how to conceive an exhibition
We focused on different forms of reception of the Classics across time/space, focusing mostly on European/US reception

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - very collaborative and strong group discussions
Weaknesses - It was fast paced, but that is common for a summer class.

This course was engaging, well planned, and well taught. I enjoyed out class discussions thoroughly and thought there was a good balance between learning about specific things that Professor Ferando wanted us to learn and exploring my own interests. That being said, this course kind of operated on the assumption that I had a decent amount of art knowledge and familiarity with classical art, which I didn't. We were often asked to find pieces of classical art as examples of topics or theories we had talked about it class, but that can be difficult when you have no familiarity with that kind of art to begin with. I think if we had done more of a groundwork establishing some of the basics of classical art, I could have engaged more with this course.

I don't really think there were any significant weaknesses. It is not necessarily a difficult course, as long as you engage with the material and conversations. Prof. Ferando was great at guiding conversation and encouraging constructive engagement.
Honestly no improvements, it was an excellent course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class. As a STEM student, I was unsure if this class was best for me. Professor Ferando encourages group discussion and is always available to talk if you want extra help. I struggled a little bit to analyze at the highest level to return to best grades, but Professor Ferando emphasises the importance of learning over grades.
Definitelyeven if you aren't interested in art history, this is a fantastic course to take which will force you to reconsider the lens through which you view art, culture, and politics.

Yes--it's a modern and balanced take on the classics and very accessible to people who have no classical background. The readings bring the classics into conversation with modern-day issues of race, tradition, gender, etc. Also, Dean Ferando is a delightful professor.
YES! Really interesting material, and a very manageable workload.

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
